choices.text: Increased renal tubular reabsorption of phosphate
ncreased calcitriol-mediated intestinal absorption of phosphate
Excess calcitonin secretion from the thyroid gland

questions.text:
A 48-year-old woman presents with chronic bone pain, fatigue, abdominal discomfort, and a recent history of renal calculi. She also complains of low mood and difficulty concentrating. X-rays of the hand reveal subperiosteal bone resorption, and her serum studies show:
Serum calcium: 11.6 mg/dL (↑)
Serum phosphate: 2.1 mg/dL (↓)
Parathyroid hormone (PTH): elevated
ALP: elevated
Which of the following best explains the underlying pathophysiology responsible for her constellation of symptoms?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The characteristic clinical features are due to PTH-induced hypercalcemia, which results from bone resorption, leading to skeletal, renal, gastrointestinal, and neuropsychiatric symptoms.

  • In primary hyperparathyroidism, excessive secretion of PTH causes:
    • Bone resorption (increased osteoclastic activity) which leads to osteitis fibrosa cystica, subperiosteal resorption, and fractures ("bones")
  • Hypercalcemia, which results in:
    • Renal stones (increased calcium filtration) - "stones"
    • Abdominal pain, constipation, peptic ulcers, pancreatitis - "groans"
    • Neuropsychiatric symptoms: depression, confusion - "moans"
  • This classic tetrad:
    • "Bones, stones, abdominal groans, and psychic moans" arise due to PTH-induced hypercalcemia and the effects of calcium on nerves, kidneys, and the GI tract.

Explanation of other options:

Increased renal tubular reabsorption of phosphate (Option A): PTH decreases phosphate reabsorption, leading to hypophosphatemia.

Increased calcitriol-mediated intestinal absorption of phosphate (Option B): PTH increases calcitriol, but the net phosphate remains low due to renal losses.

Excess calcitonin secretion (Option D): Calcitonin lowers serum calcium; it is not elevated in hyperparathyroidism.

questions.text: What is Von Recklinghausen Bone disease?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

'Von Recklinghausen's disease of bone'is a term for osteitis fibrosa cystica, the skeletal manifestation of advanced hyperparathyroidism.

  • In primary hyperparathyroidism, elevated PTH leads to increased osteoclastic activity and bone resorption, causing:
    • Subperiosteal bone resorption
    • Brown tumors (fibrocystic lesions from hemorrhage and microfractures)
    • Thinned cortex and loss of trabeculae
  • This advanced skeletal involvement is termed osteitis fibrosa cystica, also historically referred to as Von Recklinghausen's disease of bone (not to be confused with neurofibromatosis, which shares the Von Recklinghausen name).
  • Radiographic signs include:
    • Salt and pepper skull
    • Subperiosteal resorption (especially radial side of middle phalanges)
    • Brown tumors (especially in ribs, pelvis, and mandible)

Explanation of other options:

Neurofibromatosis (Option A): Also called Von Recklinghausen disease, but of the nervous system, not bone. It presents with café-au-lait spots, Lisch nodules, and neurofibromas, not bone cysts or resorption.

Tuberous sclerosis (Option B): A neurocutaneous syndrome with cortical tubers, angiofibromas, and renal angiomyolipomas; unrelated to PTH or bone resorption.

Diaphyseal aclasis (Option D): Refers to multiple hereditary exostoses, involving cartilage-capped bony projections, not cystic bone lesions.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presented with multiple pathological fractures. His serum Ca was 13.9 mg/dl, phosphate was 2.2 mg/dl, ALP was 1090. The most probable diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The combination of high calcium, low phosphate, and very high ALP with pathological fractures strongly points to primary hyperparathyroidism.

  • In primary hyperparathyroidism, overproduction of parathyroid hormone (PTH) leads to:
    • Increased osteoclastic bone resorption, weakening bones → osteitis fibrosa cystica
    • Hypercalcemia due to mobilization of calcium from bone and increased intestinal absorption
    • Hypophosphatemia due to increased renal phosphate excretion
    • Elevated ALP as osteoblasts attempt to remodel bone
  • Skeletal features may include:
    • Brown tumors (focal lytic lesions from fibrous replacement)
    • Subperiosteal resorption (especially radial border of middle phalanges)
    • Pathological fractures
  • These lab and radiologic findings are classic for advanced primary hyperparathyroidism.

Explanation of other options:

Metastasis (Option A): Can cause pathological fractures and high ALP, but usually not hypophosphatemia; hypercalcemia occurs only if associated with paraneoplastic syndrome.

Multiple myeloma (Option B): May cause hypercalcemia and fractures, but ALP is usually normal unless there is healing; also presents with normal phosphate and M-spike on electrophoresis.

Osteomalacia (Option D): Typically shows low/normal calcium, low phosphate, and high ALP, but does not present with hypercalcemia.

choices.text: Subperiosteal resorption of bone in the phalanges

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of primary hyperparathyroidism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Rugger jersey spine is a feature of renal osteodystrophy, not of primary hyperparathyroidism.

  • Hyperparathyroidism, especially primary, is characterized by increased osteoclastic activity under the influence of excess parathyroid hormone (PTH). This results in:
    • Subperiosteal bone resorption (especially along the radial border of the middle phalanges) - pathognomonic (Option D ruled out)
    • Brown tumors (fibrous tissue replacement of bone with hemorrhage and giant cells) (Option A ruled out)
    • Salt and pepper skull - due to trabecular resorption in the skull (Option C ruled out)
    • Generalized osteopenia
    • Pathological fractures
  • These findings are typical in primary hyperparathyroidism.

Brown tumors:

Skull - Salt and Pepper appearance:

Teeth - resorption of Lamina Dura:

Subperiosteal resorption of bone In the phalanges:

  • In secondary hyperparathyroidism (commonly due to chronic renal failure), similar changes can occur, but one specific feature is:
    • Rugger jersey spine: Sclerosis of the vertebral endplates with a radiolucent center. It is seen in renal osteodystrophy, not in pure primary hyperparathyroidism.

questions.text: A 55 year old male, a known case of chronic renal failure, presents with body pain and a pathological fracture of bones. What could be the cause?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In a patient with chronic renal failure, bone pain and pathological fractures point to renal osteodystrophy, a spectrum of metabolic bone changes caused by impaired phosphate excretion and secondary hyperparathyroidism.

  • Renal osteodystrophy is a collective term for skeletal abnormalities seen in chronic kidney disease (CKD). It includes:
    • Secondary hyperparathyroidism : Increased PTH leads to high bone turnover with subperiosteal resorption
    • Osteomalacia : Due to defective vitamin D activation
    • Adynamic bone disease : Low bone turnover due to PTH suppression (often from overtreatment)
  • Key features:
    • Bone pain
    • Pathological fractures
    • Growth retardation in children
    • Radiological signs like rugger jersey spine and looser zones
    • Biochemistry shows hypocalcemia, hyperphosphatemia, elevated ALP, elevated PTH
  • Treatment includes phosphate binders, vitamin D analogs, and management of secondary hyperparathyroidism.

Explanation of other options:

Osteoporosis (Option A): Typically shows normal labs except low bone density. CKD patients usually have renal osteodystrophy rather than true osteoporosis.

Adynamic bone disease (Option B): A subset of renal osteodystrophy with low bone turnover due to PTH oversuppression; however, pathological fractures with high ALP and secondary hyperparathyroidism point toward high-turnover renal bone disease.

Sarcoidosis (Option C): May cause hypercalcemia, but it does not typically cause pathological fractures and is not linked to chronic kidney disease.

questions.text: Anorexic female presented with bleeding gums, loose teeth and subperiosteal hemorrhages. What is the defect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The classic signs of scurvy (vitamin C deficiency) result from impaired hydroxylation of proline and lysine needed for stable collagen synthesis.

  • In scurvy, caused by vitamin C (ascorbic acid) deficiency, there is defective collagen formation due to failure of hydroxylation of lysine and proline residues in collagen chains. This leads to:
    • Fragile blood vessels : Petechiae, ecchymosis, subperiosteal hemorrhage
    • Poor wound healing
    • Bleeding gums, loose teeth
    • Bone pain and anemia in children
  • Vitamin C is an essential cofactor for prolyl and lysyl hydroxylase, which are required for collagen cross-linking and stability.

Explanation of other options:

Vitamin K metabolism (Option B): Leads to defective γ-carboxylation of clotting factors (II, VII, IX, X), causing coagulopathy, not connective tissue fragility or gum changes.

Von Willebrand disease (Option C): Causes mucosal bleeding and prolonged bleeding time but is not associated with loose teeth or subperiosteal hemorrhage.

Thrombocytopenia (Option D): Can cause bleeding and petechiae but does not explain collagen-related features like gum loosening or bone involvement.

Reference:

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/37795755/

questions.text: All can be used to treat osteoporosis except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Calcium is important as an adjunct but is not a definitive treatment to reverse or significantly prevent osteoporosis progression.

  • Osteoporosis management is based on:
    • Reducing bone resorption
    • Stimulating bone formation
    • Preventing fractures
  • Definitive treatment options include:
    • Denosumab: A monoclonal antibody against RANKL → inhibits osteoclast formation (Option A ruled out)
    • Teriparatide: A recombinant PTH analog → stimulates osteoblastic bone formation (Option B ruled out)
    • Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT): Used in postmenopausal women to reduce bone resorption (with caution due to CV and cancer risks) (Option C ruled out)
  • Calcium and Vitamin D:
    • Serve as supplemental therapy to support bone health, not standalone treatment
    • Help prevent hypocalcemia and aid in the action of anti-osteoporotic drugs
    • Alone, do not reverse established osteoporosis

choices.text: Defined as T score less than 2.5

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true about osteoporosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Romosozumab has a dual mechanism. It increases bone formation and decreases bone resorption, not just formation alone.

  • Romosozumab is a monoclonal antibody that targets sclerostin, a glycoprotein that inhibits osteoblasts. By inhibiting sclerostin, Romosozumab:
    • Stimulates bone formation
    • Inhibits bone resorption
  • This dual action makes it more effective in severe osteoporosis, especially in patients at high fracture risk.
  • Other key points on osteoporosis:
    • WHO defines osteoporosis as T-score ≤ -2.5 on DEXA scan (Option D ruled out)
    • Bisphosphonates (e.g., alendronate) are first-line (DOC) as they reduce osteoclast-mediated bone resorption (Option C ruled out)
    • Calcitonin, though not a first-line drug, has an analgesic effect in acute vertebral fractures (Option B ruled out)

questions.text: A lady with osteoporosis is on prolonged bisphosphonates. She develops pain in her right hip. Next investigation is?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

In this case, we have to get an x-ray to rule out an atypical fracture.

  • One of the complications of prolonged bisphosphonate therapy is the development of atypical fractures.
  • Atypical fractures occurs after drug usage of more than 5-7 year
  • It occurs due to the defective remodeling of bones, resulting from osteoclast suppression by bisphosphonates.
  • These fractures are commonly seen in the subtrochanteric region of the femur.
  • These are called atypical fractures because they involve the lateral cortex and not the medial cortex of bone as is typically seen.

questions.text:
A 65 year old female presents with back pain and kyphotic deformity of spine for the last 5 years. Her MRI is shown here. What is the diagnosis?
S
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The MRI shows biconcave vertebrae. Further, the age of the patient, female gender, back pain with kyphosis, all these are classically seen in osteoporosis.

  • Osteoporosis is a systemic skeletal disorder characterized by:
    • Reduced bone mass
    • Microarchitectural deterioration of bone tissue
    • Increased risk of fragility fractures
  • Vertebral compression fractures are among the most common clinical manifestations, often presenting as:
    • Gradual height loss
    • Thoracic or lumbar kyphosis ("dowager's hump")
    • Back pain without trauma
  • MRI findings typically show:
    • Decreased T1 and increased T2 signal intensity in acute stages
    • Multiple levels of involvement in long-standing cases
  • Risk factors: postmenopause, low calcium/vitamin D intake, inactivity, age, glucocorticoids.

Explanation of other options:

Spondylolysis (Option A): A pars interarticularis defect, often seen in young athletes with hyperextension injury; not common in elderly and doesn't cause kyphosis.

Spondylolisthesis (Option B): Forward slippage of one vertebra over another; may cause back pain but not kyphotic deformity or diffuse compression fractures.

Osteomalacia (Option D): Characterized by Looser zones and diffuse bone pain, not specifically vertebral compression or kyphosis. Also presents with hypovitaminosis D, raised ALP, and low phosphate.

questions.text: Lincoln log vertebra is seen in which condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Lincoln log vertebra refers to flattened vertebral bodies due to osteoporotic compression fractures, resembling the notched wooden logs used in Lincoln log toys.

  • In osteoporosis, vertebrae weaken and undergo anterior or central compression, leading to:
    • Wedge-shaped or biconcave vertebrae
  • Multiple vertebral compressions giving a stacked appearance (resembling Lincoln logs)
  • This occurs mainly in the thoracolumbar spine, leading to kyphosis and height loss
  • These changes are visible on lateral spine X-rays or MRI, particularly in postmenopausal women or elderly men.

Explanation of other options:

Multiple myeloma (Option A): Causes punched-out lytic lesions and vertebral collapse, not the characteristic Lincoln log stacking.

Ankylosing spondylitis (Option C): Associated with bamboo spine (syndesmophyte formation), not vertebral body flattening.

Burst fractures (Option D): Involve explosive fragmentation of vertebral body, typically traumatic and with retropulsed fragments and does not resemble Lincoln logs.

questions.text: What is a FRAX score?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

FRAX is an online tool used to estimate the 10-year probability of fractures in individuals at risk of osteoporosis. That stands for Fracture Risk Assessment Tool.

  • The FRAX (Fracture Risk Assessment Tool) was developed by the World Health Organization (WHO) to help clinicians predict a patient's 10-year risk of:
    • Hip fracture
    • Major osteoporotic fracture (hip, spine, forearm, humerus)
  • It incorporates:
    • Clinical risk factors (age, sex, smoking, alcohol, rheumatoid arthritis, glucocorticoid use, family history)
    • Bone Mineral Density (BMD) of the femoral neck (optional)
    • It aids in decision-making for initiating treatment, especially in patients with osteopenia (T-score between -1 and -2.5), where fracture risk may still be significant.
  • It uses clinical data and optional DEXA input.

questions.text: A 65-year-old postmenopausal woman presents with chronic back pain and decreased height over the past few years. A DEXA scan is performed, which reveals a T-score of -2.8 at the femoral neck. What is the most appropriate interpretation of this T-score?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A T-score ≤ -2.5 is diagnostic of osteoporosis, according to WHO criteria.

  • The T-score compares an individual's bone mineral density (BMD) to the average peak BMD of a young healthy adult of the same sex:
    • Normal: T-score ≥ -1.0 (Option A ruled out)
    • Osteopenia: T-score between -1.0 and -2.5 (Option B ruled out)
    • Osteoporosis: T-score ≤ -2.5
    • Severe osteoporosis: T-score ≤ -2.5 with a fragility fracture (Option D ruled out)
  • The DEXA scan (Dual-Energy X-ray Absorptiometry) is the gold standard for BMD assessment.

questions.text: Which condition produces a Dowager's hump?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Dowager's hump is a hallmark spinal deformity in elderly osteoporotic patients due to multiple vertebral compression fractures.

  • Dowager's hump refers to exaggerated thoracic kyphosis seen in elderly women with osteoporotic vertebral compression fractures, especially of the thoracic spine.
  • Mechanism:
    • Osteoporosis leads to weakened vertebral bodies.
    • Anterior wedge fractures cause gradual spinal curvature.
    • Over time, this results in hunchback appearance, or "dowager's hump".
  • Most commonly affects:
    • Postmenopausal women
    • Elderly individuals with poor bone density
  • This deformity also leads to reduced height, back pain, and decreased mobility.

Explanation of other options:

Tuberculosis (Option A): TB spine (Pott's disease) causes sharp angulation (gibbus deformity) due to destruction of anterior vertebral elements, not the gradual kyphosis of osteoporosis.

Ankylosing spondylitis (Option B): Causes bamboo spine and flattening of lumbar lordosis, not a kyphotic hump from vertebral collapse.

Wedge compression fracture of spine (Option D): This may contribute to kyphosis but is a radiological event, not a clinical syndrome like dowager's hump, which is a result of multiple such fractures, particularly due to osteoporosis.

questions.text: Which drug increases new bone formation as well as inhibits bone resorption in osteoporosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Strontium ranelate is the drug which has dual action in osteoporosis. It acts by both increasing the bone formation and decreasing the bone resorption.

  • Strontium ranelate is a unique anti-osteoporotic drug that:
    • Stimulates osteoblasts : Promotes bone formation
    • Inhibits osteoclasts : Reduces bone resorption
  • It mimics calcium in bone mineralization but also modulates signaling pathways that reduce osteoclast differentiation and increase osteoblast activity.
  • However, its use has declined due to concerns of:
    • Cardiovascular risk (especially in elderly)
    • DRESS syndrome (Drug Rash with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms)
  • Still, it's mechanistically important in understanding dual-action therapy in osteoporosis.

Explanation of other options:

Romosozumab (Option B): Dual-action agent like strontium ranelate, but its primary function is blocking sclerostin to increase bone formation and slightly reduce resorption. However, not classically grouped with strontium ranelate in dual-action categorization.

Teriparatide (Option C): Purely anabolic (recombinant PTH 1-34); it stimulates bone formation but does not inhibit resorption.

Risedronate (Option D): A bisphosphonate; it works by inhibiting bone resorption only through osteoclast apoptosis, no anabolic effect.

questions.text: Which of the following anti osteoporosis drugs blocks the protein 'Sclerostin'?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Romosozumab is a monoclonal antibody that specifically targets and inhibits sclerostin, thereby promoting bone formation and reducing bone resorption.

  • Sclerostin is a glycoprotein secreted by osteocytes, which inhibits the Wnt/β-catenin signaling pathway, a key regulator of osteoblast activity and bone formation.
  • Romosozumab, by blocking sclerostin, leads to:
    • Increased osteoblast activity → Increased bone formation
    • Decreased osteoclast-mediated bone resorption
  • Thus, it has a dual mechanism of action and is especially useful in patients at high fracture risk or severe osteoporosis. Administered as monthly subcutaneous injections.SS

Explanation of other options:

Abaloparatide (Option A): A PTHrP analog that stimulates bone formation, but does not inhibit sclerostin.

Denosumab (Option B): Monoclonal antibody against RANKL, inhibiting osteoclast activation, thus only decreasing resorption, with no effect on sclerostin.

Strontium ranelate (Option D): Acts by stimulating osteoblasts and inhibiting osteoclasts, but does not target sclerostin directly.

questions.text: Caffey's disease is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Caffey's disease is the classical name for infantile cortical hyperostosis, a self-limiting inflammatory disorder of infancy characterized by subperiosteal new bone formation.

Caffey's disease, or infantile cortical hyperostosis, is:

  • A rare self-limiting condition seen in infants (typically <6 months of age)
  • Presents with fever, irritability, and swelling of bones, most commonly mandible, clavicle, and long bones
  • X-rays show subperiosteal new bone formation, cortical thickening
  • Etiology: likely genetic (autosomal dominant) with inflammatory response
  • Treated with supportive care; resolves spontaneously in most cases

Explanation of other options:

Renal osteodystrophy (Option A): Refers to metabolic bone changes due to chronic kidney disease, not limited to infancy and does not cause localized cortical thickening.

Osteomyelitis of jaw (Option B): Refers to infection of the mandible, typically bacterial, and not a systemic or genetic disorder like Caffey's.

Chronic sclerosing osteomyelitis (Option C): A chronic inflammatory disorder usually in adolescents or adults, not infants, and does not match the clinical-radiological features of Caffey's disease.

choices.text: Pelvis is the most common site
High output cardiac failure may occur

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents with long-standing left hip pain, difficulty walking, and recent onset of hearing loss. On examination, there is bowing of the femur and skull enlargement. X-rays reveal coarsened trabeculae and cortical thickening of the pelvis and skull. Laboratory tests show elevated alkaline phosphatase. Which of the following statements regarding his condition is NOT true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Paget's disease can transform into secondary osteosarcoma and not chondrosarcoma.

  • Paget's disease is a chronic condition characterized by abnormal bone remodeling. First increased osteoclastic resorption followed by excessive and disorganized osteoblastic activity.
  • Key features:
    • Pelvis is the most common site (Option A ruled out)
    • Skull involvement → enlargement, cranial nerve compression (especially CN VIII → hearing loss) (Option B ruled out)
    • Spine and long bones (femur, tibia) → bowed deformities, pain
    • AV shunting in vascular bone → can cause high-output cardiac failure in extensive disease (Option C ruled out)
    • ALP is raised, with normal calcium and phosphate
    • Complication: Rare progression to osteosarcoma, not chondrosarcoma

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with persistent hip and lower back pain. Radiographs of the pelvis and spine reveal coarsened trabeculae, sclerotic changes, and a lytic lesion in the femur with a flame-shaped edge. Based on radiological findings, you suspect Paget's bone disease. Which of the following radiological findings is not typically associated with any phase of Paget's disease?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Rugger jersey spine is a classic feature of renal osteodystrophy, not Paget’s disease.

Paget's disease has three phases, each with characteristic X-ray findings:

  • Lytic Phase:
    • Increased osteoclastic activity
    • Blade of grass/flame-shaped lesion (seen in long bones) (Option B ruled out)
  • Mixed Lytic and Sclerotic Phase:
    • Most common phase
    • Coarsened trabeculae
    • Picture frame vertebrae (vertebral bodies with dense borders and central lucency) (Option A ruled out)
  • Sclerotic Phase:
    • End-stage with increased disorganized osteoblastic activity
    • Tam o' Shanter skull (calvarial thickening resembling a Scottish cap) (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: Deafness in Paget's disease is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Deafness in Paget's disease is both conductive and sensorineural.

  • Conductive because of the narrowing of the external auditory meatus and sclerosis of the ear ossicles.
  • Sensorineural because of the narrowing of the cranial nerve foramina, resulting in the compression of the vestibulocochlear nerve.

questions.text: A 4 year old child presented with progressive anemia, hepatomegaly and osteomyelitis of the jaw. X ray shows diffuse sclerosis of bone . What could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Osteomyelitis of the jaw in a child is the classical feature of osteopetrosis.

  • Osteopetrosis is also called Marble bone disease/Albers Schonberg disease
  • It is a congenital condition characterized by defective osteoclastic resorption of immature bone, resulting in its accumulation throughout the skeleton, causing increased frequency of long bone fractures, cranial nerve palsies, pancytopenia and low back pain.
  • Clinical feature include:
    • Low back pain
    • Pathological fractures
    • Progressive anemia
    • Severe infections: Mandible osteomyelitis
    • Easy bruising
    • Failure to thrive
    • Cranial N 2, 7, 8 palsy leading to blindness and deafness

questions.text: All are true regarding osteopetrosis except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Fracture healing is typically normal in osteopetrosis, despite increased bone density and brittleness.

  • Osteopetrosis is also called Marble bone disease / Albers Schonberg disease
  • It is a congenital condition characterized by defective osteoclastic resorption of immature bone resulting in its accumulation throughout the skeleton, causing increased frequency of long bone fractures, cranial nerve palsies, pancytopenia and low back pain.
  • Clinical feature include
    • Low back pain
    • Pathological fractures
    • Progressive anemia
    • Severe infections : Mandible osteomyelitis
    • Easy bruising
    • Failure to thrive
    • Cranial N 2, 7, 8 palsy leading to blindness and deafness

Explanation of other options:

Defective osteoclastic bone resorption (Option A): This is the pathological hallmark of osteopetrosis.

Cranial nerve involvement (Option B): Thickened bones compress cranial nerves, especially CN II and CN VIII.

Osteomyelitis (Option C): Common due to poor vascularity and dense bone, especially in the mandible.

questions.text: Identify the given X-ray. Which of the following conditions does this patient suffer from?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given x-ray shows a Banana fracture. Banana fractures are seen in Paget's disease.

  • Complications of Paget's disease include
    • Fractures - Banana Fractures
    • Cranial N palsy 2, 5, 7 & 8
    • Deafness - Conductive and sensorineural
    • Spinal canal stenosis
    • High output cardiac failure - MC cause of death
    • Steal syndrome
    • Osteosarcoma -1% risk

questions.text: Which of the conditions produce wormian bones?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Wormian bones are extra sutural bones seen commonly in osteogenesis imperfecta due to defective collagen formation and bone fragility.

  • Osteogenesis imperfecta (OI) is a congenital disorder of Type I collagen synthesis. It leads to:
    • Bone fragility and frequent fractures
    • Blue sclerae
    • Hearing loss (due to abnormal middle ear bones)
    • Dentinogenesis imperfecta
  • Wormian bones: These are small, irregular bones that form within the cranial sutures, most commonly lambdoid suture
  • Wormian bones are present in over 60-80% of OI cases and are due to disordered ossification of the skull, a reflection of defective collagen.

Explanation of other options:

Scurvy (Option A): Scurvy leads to subperiosteal hemorrhages and white line of Frankel, not wormian bones.

Osteopetrosis (Option B): Osteopetrosis shows bone within bone appearance, Erlenmeyer flask deformity, but not wormian bones.

Paget's disease (Option D): Paget's disease shows a cotton wool skull and Tam o' Shanter skull, but not wormian bones.

questions.text: Shish kebab osteotomy is used for the treatment of which condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Shish kebab osteotomy is used for the treatment of osteogenesis imperfecta.

  • In OI, there are severe deformities of long bones of the body.
  • These occur due to recurrent fractures of the fragile bones which malunite to produce gross deformities.
  • Surgical correction of any deformity of bone requires cutting the bone and straightening it and fixing it in the corrected position.
  • This procedure is called osteotomy.
  • In OI, because of the severe deformities, a single bone may have to be osteotomized at multiple places and realigned to achieve correction.
  • This procedure is similar to preparing shish kebab, where multiple pieces of meat are threaded on a skewer.

questions.text: In which condition are endo bones seen?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Endo Bones are seen in osteopetrosis.

X ray findings in osteopetrosis

  • Diffuse sclerosis of bones
  • Lack of cortico - cancellous differentiation
  • Narrow/ Absent medullary canal
  • Endo Bones ('Os in Os' appearance)
  • Sandwich vertebrae
  • Erlenmeyer flask appearance
